name: Luangwa Community Forests Project

credit_type.verbose_name: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

short_description: The Luangwa Community Forests Project is a large-scale REDD+ project implemented in Eastern and Lusaka Province, Zambia, with a total project area of 1036666 ha. The project is designed to generate emissions reductions through avoided deforestation.
description:
The Luangwa Community Forests Project is a large-scale REDD+ project implemented in Eastern and Lusaka Province, Zambia, with an initial project area of 943,676 ha. A second project instance was added in 2021, comprising 92,990 ha, bringing the total project area to 1,036,666 ha.

The project is being implemented on communal land in 12 chiefdoms falling within Game Management Areas (GMA) and two private ranches. Implementation is in partnership with the traditional authorities and the government of the Republic of Zambia.

The project will generate emissions reductions through avoided deforestation, using the following mitigation activities: A combination of direct conservation support (forest monitoring and encroachment prevention) engagement and capacity building with key Government and community stakeholders, and conservation incentives for the area protected, including performance-based payments delivered to empowered community stakeholders through local institutions, and support to deforestation mitigation activities, including sustainable, improved livelihoods activities.

sustainable_development_goals.verbose_name: Goal 16: Peace, Justice And Strong Institutions

co_benefits:
Conservation of biodiversity in the Lusaka province
Support of social development for communities living in the area

name: Katingan Peatland Restoration and Conservation Project

name: Katingan Peatland Restoration and Conservation Project

name: Rimba Raya Biodiversity Reserve Project

credit_type.verbose_name: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

short_description: The Rimba Raya Biodiversity Reserve Project is an initiative by InfiniteEARTH, which aims to reduce Indonesia's emissions by preserving almost 65,000 hectares of tropical peat swamp forest.
description:
The Rimba Raya Biodiversity Reserve Project, an initiative by InfiniteEARTH, aims to reduce Indonesia’s emissions by preserving almost 65,000 hectares of tropical peat swamp forest.

The area is rich in biodiversity, including the endangered Bornean Orangutan, and was originally slated by the provincial government to be converted into four palm oil estates.

Located on the southern coast of Borneo in the province of Central Kalimantan, the project is also designed to protect the integrity of the adjacent world-renowned Tanjung Puting National Park by creating a physical buffer zone on the full extent of the eastern border of the park which has a length of about 90 km (56 miles).

sustainable_development_goals.verbose_name: Goal 16: Peace, Justice And Strong Institutions

co_benefits:
"Physicial buffer" created by help of carbon sales
Provision of employment opportunities for local communities

name: Brazil Nut Concessions Project

credit_type.verbose_name: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

short_description: The project aims to prevent deforestation and preserve environmental integrity in high-quality rainforest. It helps establishing initiatives which will increase both the value of the healthy forest and the income generated through sustainable Brazil nut harvesting.
description:
BAM has entered into a long-term partnership with the Madre de Dios Federation of Brazil nut Concessioners (FEPROCAMD) aimed at preventing deforestation and preserving environmental integrity in high-quality rainforest.

The project is helping to establish initiatives which will increase both the value of the healthy forest and the income generated through sustainable Brazil nut harvesting, empowering concessioners to protect and maintain their forest.

Currently, concessioners’ activity is limited to subsistence Brazil nut collection and, in a very few cases, subsistence forestry, so their long-term wellbeing is highly dependent on the health of local ecosystems. On the other hand, illegal deforestation on concession land has increased due to the Interoceanic Highway, passing through Madre de Dios region.

The project helps protect the rainforest from invasion of illegal loggers and miners from across Peru and the neighboring countries. In addition, the project aims to increase concessioners’ income from sustainable harvest of brazil nuts and contribute to the region's sustainable development.
co_benefits:
Implementation of socio-environmental management plan
Promotion of non-timber production

name: Madre de Dios Amazon REDD+ Project

credit_type.verbose_name: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

short_description: The Madre de Dios Amazon REDD Project protects approximately 100,000 hectares of rainforest in the Peruvian Amazon and aims to help reduce deforestation, while protecting endangered species and preserving the habitat of local indigenous communities
description:
The Madre de Dios Amazon REDD Project protects approximately 100,000 hectares of rainforest in the Peruvian Amazon and is located about 400 km (250 miles) northeast of Machu Picchu, the "lost city of the Incas" in the triangle of Peru, Brazil and Bolivia.

The area lies close to the new inter-oceanic road that has been linking Brazil with Peruvian ports on the Pacific Ocean for some time and is driving the development of the remote region.

The project is also located in a region that is part of the ecologically valuable Vilcabamba-Amboró corridor, one of the world's largest known biodiversity hotspots, where it aims to help reduce deforestation in the Peruvian Amazon, while protecting endangered species (jaguar, howler monkey, anteater, macaw) and preserving the habitat of local indigenous communities (Yine and Huitoto tribal communities), which depend on an intact forest ecosystem.
co_benefits:
Promotion of sustainable agriculture and forestry practices
Protection of numerous endangered species of flora and fauna 
Stabilization of regional water cycles

name: The Russas Project

credit_type.verbose_name: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

short_description: The Russas Project seeks to help protect and conserve tropical forest by providing payments for ecosystem services. It is designed to mitigate deforestation pressures using a combination of environmental and social programs.
description:
The Russas Project seeks to help protect and conserve tropical forest in an area of almost 42,000 hectares by providing payments for ecosystem services. Project activities intended to reduce deforestation are implemented in and around a privately-owned property in the state of Acre, Brazil, and are funded by payments related to emission reduction credits generated by the project.

The project is being developed and registered under the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) and the Climate, Community and Biodiversity Standard (CCBS). Its development involved cooperation with local communities in the surrounding of the project area, engaging Acre state officials working on similar strategies at a regional/state level, developing a plan to lower the pressure on land and forest resources in consultation with the local communities, and putting into operation the REDD project implementation plan.
co_benefits:
Protection and conservation of biodiversity in the region
Improvement of communities' livelihoods through social programs

name: Pacajai REDD+ Project

credit_type.verbose_name: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

short_description: Pacajai REDD+ is a project designed to stop deforestation of native forests in the state of Pará in the municipality of Portel, Brazil. It will generate multiple climate, social, and biodiversity benefits through a 40 years project lifetime.
description:
Pacajai REDD+ is a project designed to stop deforestation of native forests in the state of Pará in the municipality of Portel, Brazil. It will generate multiple climate, social, and biodiversity benefits and avoid the net emission of 22 million tCO2e through a 40 years project lifetime.

The project’s objectives will be achieved by the strategic management of land within the 135,000 ha project area, including the development and implementation of a management plan in cooperation with local communities. By that a sustainable use of land and local resources will be enabled, especially through the protection and monitoring of endangered areas by specially trained rangers and forest managers.

The project will increase the communities’ quality of life as well as protect local ecosystems, allowing forest regeneration as a medium-term goal.

sustainable_development_goals.verbose_name: Goal 16: Peace, Justice And Strong Institutions

co_benefits:
Conservation of biodiversity and regeneration of forest
Enhancement of community's organizational capabilities for better management of local resources
Regulation of region's climate

name: Southern Cardamom REDD+ Project

credit_type.verbose_name: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

short_description: The Southern Cardamom REDD+ Project (SCRP) is an initiative designed to promote climate change mitigation and adaptation, maintain biodiversity and create alternative livelihoods in the parts of Southern Cardamom National Park and Tatai Wildlife Sanctuary.
description:
The Southern Cardamom REDD+ Project (SCRP) is an initiative designed to promote climate change mitigation and adaptation, maintain biodiversity and create alternative livelihoods. The 445,339 ha project area encompasses parts of Southern Cardamom National Park and Tatai Wildlife Sanctuary and will protect a critical part of the Cardamom Mountains Rainforest Ecoregion – one of the 200 most important locations for biodiversity conservation on the planet.

The project will directly support the livelihoods of 21 villages in nine communes around the perimeter of the project area and provide educational scholarships to eight additional villages, or around 16,500 inhabitants. Its climate benefits include the avoided emission of approximately 12 million t CO2e during the first monitoring period and over 115,000 million t CO2e over the lifetime of the project.
Furthermore, the project will generate substantial community and biodiversity co-benefits by designing new and sustainable livelihood opportunities, such as direct employment, alternative income generating activities and initiatives to stimulate investment in businesses. By that, pressure on the environment will be reduced while significantly increasing community well-being. Additional programs will address food security, improve health and education facilities, as well as raise environmental awareness.

Biodiversity co-benefits will be achieved through greater protection of the ecosystem, predominantly by means of increased security and improved monitoring. The project will also be protecting critical habitat for significant populations of many IUCN listed species, including Asian elephant, Asian black bear, sun bear, large spotted civet, clouded leopard, and dhole, as well as the critically endangered reptiles Siamese crocodile and Southern river terrapin.
project_developer: Royal Government of Cambodia (RGC), Ministry of Environment

sustainable_development_goals.verbose_name: Goal 16: Peace, Justice And Strong Institutions

co_benefits:
Scholarships for a four-year bachelor’s degree at Royal University of Phnom Penh and Royal University of Agriculture for youth from project communities
Employment, income generation activities, and initiatives to stimulate investment in businesses
Greater protection of ecosystem by using increased security and improved monitoring

name: NIHT Topaiyo REDD+ Project

credit_type.verbose_name: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

short_description: NIHT Inc. has partnered with the traditional landowners of New Ireland and East New Britain to put an end to deforestation initiated by industrial logging in the region in Papua New Guinea. What began as a traditional timber operation has been recognized as an opportunity with enormous carbon sequestering potential.
description:
NIHT Inc. has partnered with the traditional landowners of New Ireland and East New Britain to put an end to deforestation initiated by industrial logging in the region. The preservation of these rainforests is essential to not only the carbon and biodiversity benefits inherent with projects of this nature, but also for the wellbeing and prosperity of the people in these areas.

The project is located in the forested areas of New Ireland and East New Britain in Papua New Guinea and has evolved based on the input and needs expressed by people living in the region. What began as a traditional timber operation has been recognized as an opportunity with enormous carbon sequestering potential, and has evolved into a forest protection project that will provide substantial economic benefits to the people of Papua New Guinea.

Through the avoidance of carrying out exploitative industrial commercial timber harvesting in the project area, the project expects to generate nearly 60 million tons of CO2 emissions reductions across the 30 year project lifetime, depending on the number and size of Project Activity Instances (PAIs) added to the project.

sustainable_development_goals.verbose_name: Goal 16: Peace, Justice And Strong Institutions

co_benefits:
Protection of local forests and biodiversity
Creation of valuable source of alternative income for landowners and communities

name: Tambopata Forest Protection Project

credit_type.verbose_name: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

short_description: The Reduction of Deforestation and Degradation in Tambopata National Reserve and Bahuaja-Sonene National Park in the Madre Dios region is a project designed to conserve forests against deforestation and promote sustainable economic activities.
description:
Located in the area of Tambopata National Reserve and the sector of Bahuaja-Sonene National Park in the Madre de Dios region, this project is designed to reduce deforestation and degradation and help Brazil nut farmers to officially declare and protect their land. Both Natural Protected Areas (NPA) politically belong to the Peruvian Tambopata province and have a combined area of 573,299 hectares.

The project purpose is to conserve forests from both NPAs against deforestation and to to change land-use at the NPAs Buffer Zone by promoting sustainable economic activities and establishing conservation agreements at previously identified critical areas. By that, local communities are able to participate in the management of the NPAs.

Additionally, technical support is provided to regional authorities for forest and environmental governance of the Madre de Dios region, enhancing state participation and optimizing coordination and collaboration between authorities and local population.

sustainable_development_goals.verbose_name: Goal 16: Peace, Justice And Strong Institutions

co_benefits:
Estimated net emissions reductions in the project area
Protection of critically endangered species or species in danger of extinction

name: The Valparaiso Project

credit_type.verbose_name: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

short_description: The Valparaiso Project seeks to help protect and conserve tropical forest by providing payments for ecosystem services. Project activities intended to reduce deforestation are implemented in and around a privately-owned property in the state of Acre, Brazil.
description:
The Valparaiso Project seeks to help protect and conserve tropical forest in an area of about 28,000 hectares by providing payments for ecosystem services. Project activities intended to reduce deforestation are implemented in and around a privately-owned property in the state of Acre, Brazil, and are funded by payments related to emission reduction credits generated by the project.

The project is being developed and registered under the Verified Carbon Standard (VCS) and the Climate, Community and Biodiversity Standard (CCBS). Its development involved cooperation with local communities in the surrounding of the project area, engaging Acre state officials working on similar strategies at a regional/state level, developing a plan to lower the pressure on land and forest resources in consultation with the local communities, and putting into operation the REDD project implementation plan.
co_benefits:
Community outreach and education, as well as employment of local community members
Share of carbon related revenue with communities living on Valparaiso property

name: REDD+ Project Resguardo Indígena Unificado de la Selva de Matavén (RIU-SM)

credit_type.verbose_name: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

short_description: The project aims to achieve the establishment of an integrated management system of forests and lands  to ensure their sustainability and to mitigate threats of their conservation.
description:
The REDD+ Project Resguardo Indígena Unificado de la Selva de Matavén (RIU-SM) aims to develop a participatory process to achieve the establishment of an integrated management system of forests and lands of the reserve, to ensure its sustainability and to mitigate threats of its conservation, particularly avoiding deforestation and providing compensation payments for ecosystem services.

The technology corresponds to a REDD Project in accordance with standards established by the VCS, specifically "Avoiding Unplanned Deforestation and Degradation" (AUDD).

The Indigenous Reservation is located east of the high plain Orinoco Colombian region in the transition belt between the savannas of the Orinoco and the Amazon forests, in the Department of Vichada.

sustainable_development_goals.verbose_name: Goal 16: Peace, Justice And Strong Institutions

co_benefits:
Conservation and restoration of biodiversity
Support of social development through compensation payments for ecosystem services

name: Yunnan Kunming Liangqu Improved Forest Management Project

credit_type.verbose_name: Agriculture Forestry and Other Land Use

short_description: The Yunnan Kunming Liangqu Improved Forest Management Project is located in Lianhe Township and Zhuanlong Town and is implemented to protect the once logging forest.
description:
The Yunnan Kunming Liangqu Improved Forest Management Project is located in Lianhe Township and Zhuanlong Town in Kunming City in the Yunnan Province, China. It is implemented by Kunming Yuming Investment Development Co. Ltd. to protect the once logging forest and comprises almost 6,900 ha.

Before the implementation of the project, the forest within the area was designed and planted as commercial forest. The project's main objective is to improve its coverage rate, protect the local ecological environment, reduce carbon emissions and carbon sequestration by enhancing the management level and convert logged into protected forest.
project_developer: Kunming Yuming Investment Development Co., Ltd.
co_benefits:
Conservation of biodiversity
Support of social development in the area
